awd_titl_txt: Precision Math: Using Interactive Gaming Technology to Build Student Proficiency in the Foundational Concepts and Problem Solving Skills of Measurement and Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Strong knowledge of measurement and data analysis is essential to ensure competiveness of the nation as a whole and full access to educational and work opportunities for all students. Despite this importance, a considerable number of U.S. students, particularly students from poor and minority backgrounds, struggle with these two areas of mathematics. The purpose of this 4-year Research and Development project, Precision Mathematics (PM): Building Student Proficiency in the Foundational Concepts and Problem Solving Skills of Measurement and Data Analysis, is to improve student mathematics achievement by developing a mathematics intervention focused on key measurement and data analysis skills. The PM intervention will be designed for first and second grade students who are experiencing mathematics difficulties. To increase student mathematics achievement, the intervention will include: (a) a technology-based component that will provide students with individualized instruction and (b) hands-on activities that will offer opportunities for students to interact with their teacher and peers around critical measurement and data analysis concepts. Primary activities of the project will include intervention development, pilot testing, data analysis, and intervention revision. One primary benefit of PM is that it will provide struggling learners with meaningful access to critical concepts and skills identified in the Common Core State Standards Initiative. Another benefit is that will be designed to serve as a foundation for students to understand more advanced mathematical concepts introduced in the later grades. PM has the potential to address a concerning gap in U.S. education. To date, intervention research focused on measurement and data analysis is scant.

Proficiency with measurement and data analysis is essential for obtaining occupations in the STEM fields. A primary aim of this project is to develop PM, a mathematics intervention designed to teach key concepts of measurement and data analysis to at-risk 1st and 2nd grade students. Comprising the intervention will be technology-based and collaborative problem-solving activities. At each grade, the intervention will provide 20 hours of instruction focused on topics identified in the Common Core State Standards. A primary aim of the project is to develop the intervention using a design science approach, including a mix of qualitative and quantitative research methods that will guide iterative testing and revision cycles. A second primary aim is to test the promise of the intervention to improve student mathematics achievement. Rigorous pilot studies (i.e., randomized controlled trials) will be conducted in 1st and 2nd grade classrooms involving over 700 at-risk students. Within classrooms, students will be randomly assigned to treatment (PM) or control conditions (business as usual). Two research questions will be addressed: (a) What is the potential promise of the intervention when delivered in authentic education settings? (b) Based on empirical evidence, are revisions to the intervention's theory of change necessary? Tests of main effects of intervention effects will be conducted using analysis of covariance models, adjusting for pretest scores. Generated findings are anticipated to contribute to the knowledge base on early STEM learning for at-risk learners.

por.por_cntn:
Measurement and statistical investigation are areas of mathematics that hold significant importance in students? pursuit of achieving mathematical proficiency. For example, strong problem-solving skills around foundational concepts of measurement and statistical investigation can help lay the foundation for working with more advanced mathematics, such as fractions, variability, and sampling distributions. A robust understanding of measurement and statistical investigation is also essential in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Civil engineers, for example, use measurement to obtain precise estimates of mass and strain, whereas an epidemiologist will collect and analyze data to identify trends in health-related events, such as the epidemic spread of COVID-19. Despite these affordances, measurement and statistical investigation are areas of mathematics visibly neglected in educational intervention research. Unfortunately, the implications of these empirical shortcomings are likely greatest for students from marginalized and underserved communities. To promote equitable access to foundational concepts of measurement and statistical investigation, the Precision Mathematics project addressed two primary aims. First, in the initial years of the project, we designed first- and second-grade mathematics interventions focused on improving students? mathematics achievement in the areas of measurement and statistical investigation. Second, in the project?s final years, we separately tested the promise of each intervention by conducting methodologically rigorous pilot studies (i.e., randomized controlled trials). Notably, results from both pilot studies indicated the first- and second-grade interventions had positive effects on student mathematics achievement. Collectively, these findings suggested students were able to participate in well-designed and delivered mathematics learning opportunities.

            Across this multi-year project, researchers from the University of Oregon and The University of Texas at Austin developed two fully featured early mathematics interventions designed for first and second-grade students at risk for mathematics difficulties. Because the field of education largely ignores the call from instructional designers to embrace a scientific approach in the development of mathematics programs, our team utilized an empirical design process to develop the two interventions. Each intervention is intended to be delivered in small-group instructional formats (i.e., four to five students per interventionist), 30-min per day, four days per week for eight weeks. Conceptually, the Precision Mathematics interventions were designed to directly supplement the core mathematics instruction delivered in first- and second-grade classrooms, respectively. Each intervention offers daily technology-based activities intended to build students? conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills. Our rationale for including these types of activities largely stems from the push to integrate education technology into today?s classrooms. Complementing the technology-based activities are hands-on investigations designed to promote tactile learning experiences for students to work with concrete objects and different measurement tools.

            By developing and testing the first- and second-grade Precision Mathematics interventions, we contend that a number of broader issues related to increasing student mathematics outcomes in the areas of measurement and statistical investigation were addressed in this project. Arguably, this work impacts society through and beyond the school years of students at risk for mathematics difficulties in the sense that it facilitated relevant ?real-world? opportunities and positive experiences in mathematics. The work also helped the field better understand the practices that ameliorate the mathematics problems that students encounter in the early elementary grades. This is critical because students? early success in mathematics can influence their motivation to pursue STEM fields of study. The demand for a STEM literate workforce continues to increase due to today?s global economy. As such, it stands to reason to provide high-quality STEM-related instruction to all students, including students with or at risk for mathematics difficulties. A related issue is how this project addressed calls from the field of education to advance equity and eliminate disparities in STEM education for students most vulnerable for academic risk. Collectively, our project included over 500 first- and second grade students. Another broader impact of our work was building general capacity in service delivery models of early STEM learning. Mathematics intervention programs, like the Precision Mathematics interventions, lie at the core of these models. Therefore, given their focus on measurement and data analysis, these interventions can complement existing ones focused on whole number and operations. The Precision Mathematics project also addresses a significant void in the current knowledge base. Few instructional tools in the areas of measurement and statistical investigation are available for students at risk for mathematics difficulties. As further contributions to the field, Precision Mathematics research has been published in prestigious scholarly journals within and outside our immediate discipline. For example, findings from the first-grade pilot study were published in Exceptional Children, whereas the second-grade results were published in the Journal of Educational Psychology. Both journals offer some of the highest impact factors in the field of education. Finally, the Precision Mathematics scholarly work has been disseminated in 14 peer-reviewed publications and at numerous professionally recognized educational research conferences.
